case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 790 of 1957 filed by State of Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 790 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 10, 1954,

facts.text: Appeal from Allahabad High Court judgment dated February 10, 1954 in Civil Misc. Writ No. 280 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 10, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 280 of 1950. B. Aggarwala, G. C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the appellants.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 11, 1960 by Mudholkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.-This is an appeal by the State of Uttar Pradesh against the decision of the Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court in a writ petition.

facts.text: Respondents challenged orders under s. 3(b) United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 requiring bonus for 1947-48 and 1948-49 and retaining allowances

anchor.surface_text: In the writ petition the respondents challenged certain orders made by the Government of Uttar Pradesh under s. 3, cl. b of the United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, XXVIII of 1947 requiring the respondents to pay bonus at certain rates for the years 1947-48 and 1948-49 to their workers and also payment of retaining allowances to the skilled seasonal workmen and clerical staff.

facts.text: Indian National Sugar Mills Workers Federation served notices on sugar factories in Uttar Pradesh on December 15, 1949 making six demands including bonus for 1948-49 and restoration of previous years bonus reduction

anchor.surface_text: The Indian National Sugar Mills Workers Federation, Lucknow, served notices on various sugar factories in Uttar Pradesh on December 15, 1949, in which they made six demands. We need, however, mention only one of them as that alone is in controversy in this appeal. That demand related to the bonus for the year 1948-49 and to the restoration of the reduction which had been made in the previous years bonus.

facts.text: Federation threatened strike from January 16, 1960 if demands not met

anchor.surface_text: By that notice the Federation threatened a strike in the industry with effect from January 16, 1960, if the demands were not met by the sugar factories.

facts.text: Government of Uttar Pradesh appointed Court of Inquiry and referred dispute under ss. 6 and 10 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: Since this situation brought into existence an industrial dispute, the Government of Uttar Pradesh, in exercise of the power conferred by ss. 6 and 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, XIV of 1947 appointed a Court of Inquiry and referred the dispute to it.

facts.text: Notification for Court of Inquiry twice amended

anchor.surface_text: The notification also stated the points which were referred to the Court of Inquiry. That notification was twice amended but nothing turns on those amendments.

facts.text: Court of Inquiry held full enquiry with representations from employers and employees

anchor.surface_text: A full enquiry was held by the Court of Inquiry at which the representatives of both the employers as well as the employees were represented and material was placed before the Court of Inquiry by both the sides.

facts.text: Court of Inquiry submitted report on April 15, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The Court of Inquiry submitted its report to the Government on April 15, 1950.

facts.text: Government published report in Uttar Pradesh Gazette on May 8, 1950 under s.17 Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this report the Government of Uttar Pradesh published the report in the Uttar Pradesh gazette on May 8, 1950, as provided for in s. 17 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Government issued notification on July 5, 1950 under s.3(b) UP Industrial Disputes Act directing sugar factories to pay bonus for 1947-48 and 1948-49 and retaining allowance from off season 1950

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1950, the Government of Uttar Pradesh, in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 3 b of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, issued a notification directing the various sugar factories to pay bonus to their workmen for the year 1948-49 as well as to pay certain amounts as bonus for the year 1947-48. A further direction was made in the notification for payment of retaining allowance to the skilled seasonal workmen and clerical staff with effect from the off season in the year 1950.

facts.text: Indian Sugar Millers Association filed writ petition under Art. 226 against enforcement of notification, dismissed on September 14, 1950 for no legal interest

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Indian Sugar Millers Association, which is an Association of sugar factories in India and is registered under the Trade Union Act made a petition before the High Court at Allahabad under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ against the Government of Uttar Pradesh prohibiting the Government from enforcing the notification. The writ petition was dismissed by the High Court on September 14, 1950, on the ground that the Association had no legal interest in the matter.

facts.text: Various sugar mills including respondents filed separate writ petitions before Allahabad High Court

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon various sugar mills preferred separate writ petitions before the High Court, the respondents before us being one of them.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed writ petitions regarding payment of bonus

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Allahabad allowed the writ petitions, in so far as the question of payment of bonus was concerned,

facts.text: Sapru J of High Court expressed doubt on invalidity of State Government order on bonus

anchor.surface_text: though Sapru, J., one of the judges constituting the Full Bench, expressed a doubt as to the correctness of the view that the order of the State Government as regards the payment of bonus was invalid.

facts.text: State of UP applied for certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) and (c), granted by High Court

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of the High Court, the State of Uttar Pradesh applied for a certificate under Art. 133 1 b and Art. 133 1 c of the Constitution. The High Court having granted the certificate,

facts.text: High Court held s.3(b) prospective only, cannot require past bonus payment

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court was that clause b of s. 3 of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, is prospective in operation in that thereunder it is open to the State Government to ask an employer or an employee to observe a term or a condition of employment in future and that consequently it is not competent thereunder to require an employer to pay bonus to workmen in respect of a period of employment which is already past.

facts.text: Supreme Court held direction to pay past bonus is condition of future employment, not retrospective

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with the learned judges of the Allahabad High Court that cl. b of s. 3 cannot be given a retrospective effect. But we are unable to agree with them that the State Government in making a direction to the employers to pay bonus for the years in question purported to give a retrospective operation to the provisions of that clause.

facts.text: Bonus payable only to workers who worked in 1947-48 and 1948-49, not new employees

anchor.surface_text: The answer to that is that under the order of the Government such bonus is payable only to those workers who had worked during the years in question and not to new employees.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside High Court order quashing bonus payment direction

anchor.surface_text: Upon this view we hold that the High Court was in error in issuing a writ against the State Government quashing their order in so far as it related to payment of bonus. The appeal is allowed and order of the High Court is set aside.

facts.text: Government notification directed bonus payment within six weeks of order

anchor.surface_text: This payment was directed to be made within six weeks of the making of the order.

facts.text: Industrial dispute existed when impugned order made

anchor.surface_text: It must not be forgotten that the dispute was in the present, that is, it existed when the impugned order was made, though its origin was in the past.

facts.text: s.3(b) for emergency situations as temporary measure

anchor.surface_text: Clause b of s. 3 was apparently enacted for this purpose. An order made thereunder would be in the nature of a temporary or interim order as would be clear from the words for such period as may be specified appearing therein
under s. 3, cl.  b  of the United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,  XXVIII of 1947  requiring the respondents to pay bonus at certain rates for the years 1947-48 and 1948-49 to their workers

concepts.unlisted_label: Proviso to S.3 UP Industrial Disputes Act

issues.text: Whether clause b of s. 3 of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 operates retrospectively or must be construed as having prospective operation only?

anchor.surface_text: Clause b of s. 3 does not operate retrospectively and must be construed as having a prospective operation only.

issues.text: Whether clause b of s. 3 applies where an industrial dispute has arisen and whether cl. d is the appropriate provision for such cases?

anchor.surface_text: This clause does not apply at all where an industrial dispute has arisen and that the appropriate provision under which the State Government can take action where an industrial dispute has arisen is cl. d .

issues.text: Whether clause b of s. 3 is ultra vires, violative of Art. 14 and Art. 19(1)(g) of the Constitution if applicable even when an industrial dispute has arisen?

anchor.surface_text: If cl. b is susceptible of the interpretation that it is applicable even when an industrial dispute has arisen then it is ultra vires in as much as it would enable the State Government to discriminate between an industry and an industry or an industrial unit and another industrial unit or between a workman and a workman by referring some cases for adjudication to an industrial court under cl. d and passing executive order itself in respect of others. The provisions of cl. b , according to him, are violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution. Further, according to him, they are also violative of the provisions of Art. 19 1 g

arguments.claim: Clause b of s. 3 of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, is prospective in operation and cannot require payment of bonus for past employment periods

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court was that clause b of s. 3 of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, is prospective in operation in that thereunder it is open to the State Government to ask an employer or an employee to observe a term or a condition of employment in future and that consequently it is not competent thereunder to require an employer to pay bonus to workmen in respect of a period of employment which is already past.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed which is as follows It appears from the language that this provision was number meant for the purpose of dealing with individual disputes arising o

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees no retrospective effect but direction imposes future condition not retrospective

arguments.claim: Provisions of clause b wide enough to permit direction to pay past bonus as condition of future employment

anchor.surface_text: According to the State the provisions of the aforesaid clause are wide enough to permit the making of such a direction to the employer because by doing so the State Government would only be imposing a condition of employment in future.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: for the purpose of enabling the State Government to vary the agreed terms and companyditions of employment for purposes specified in a. 3 of U. P. Ind

arguments.court_reasoning: Direction attaches condition to 1950-51 employment; bonus payable only to past workers

arguments.claim: Clause b of s. 3 does not operate retrospectively and must be construed as prospective only

anchor.surface_text: Clause b of s. 3 does not operate retrospectively and must be construed as having a prospective operation only.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot give retrospective effect to cl. b

anchor.surface_text: If cl. b is susceptible of the interpretation that it is applicable even when an industrial dispute has arisen then it is ultra vires in as much as it would enable the State Government to discriminate between an industry and an industry or an industrial unit and another industrial unit or between a workman and a workman by referring some cases for adjudication to an industrial court under cl. d and passing executive order itself in respect of others. The provisions of cl. b , according to him, are violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution. Further, according to him, they are also violative of the provisions of Art. 19 1 g

arguments.court_reasoning: Limit cl. b to emergencies via construction; no discrimination; temporary restriction under Art.19(6)

arguments.claim: Bonus is a wage, matter of contract, cannot be imposed as condition of employment by government

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak contended that bonus has certain attributes of a wage and wage being a matter of contract can only be a term of employment agreed to between the employer and the employee but could not be a condition of employment which could be imposed by a statute or which could be imposed by a Government acting under a statute.

arguments.court_reasoning: Minimum Wages Act example of statutory wage condition; s.3 empowers imposing terms

arguments.claim: Order adds new term for already past period per Bhargava J.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak then referred to the following observations in the judgment of Bhargava, J. Obviously there can be no question of requiring any one to observe for a future period terms and conditions of employment which have already remained effective and have already been carried out by those persons .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nature of a tempor- ary or interim order as would be clear from the words for such period as may be specified appearing therein and from the second p

arguments.court_reasoning: Order requires additional payment as future work condition

arguments.claim: Payment of bonus to new employees contrary to conception of bonus

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak, however, said that this would involve payment of bonus even to new employees, that is, those who had not participated in earning the profits in the past and that this would be contrary to the very conception of bonus.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tate Government. It would, therefore, follow from this that where the Government has made an executi

arguments.court_reasoning: Bonus only to workers who worked in those years, not new employees

arguments.claim: Personnel change immaterial; payment regarded as essential condition for future work - Sapru J.

anchor.surface_text: As has been rightly pointed out by Sapru, J., The employees might well have taken in the industrial dispute the line that the payment of bonus in respect of the years 1947-48 and 1948-49 to the workmen employed in those years was regarded by those who were employed in future as a preliminary and essential condition for not only the settlement of the industrial dispute in progress but also for carrying on their future work in sugar factories .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r adjudication under cl.  d . But in our opinion w

arguments.claim: Cl. b meant for future terms, not enforcing past per Bhargava J. in L.D. Sugar Mills

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak then relied upon the following observations of Bhargava, J., in L. D. Sugar Mills v. U. P. Government The expression 1 to observe for such period as may be specified, such terms and conditions of employment as may be determined gives an indication that clause b of s. 3 of the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, is meant for the purpose of passing orders by which the Government gives directions about what the terms and conditions of employment should be and not how a particular term and condition of employment already in existence should be acted upon.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: may necessitate the exercise of powers under cl.  b  and a mere resort to those under cl.  d  may be inadequate to meet this situation. Whether to re

arguments.court_reasoning: Bhargava reversed by appellate bench in Ram Nath Koeri; court agrees with appellate

arguments.claim: Normal way for industrial dispute is judicial process under cl. d, not executive cl. b

anchor.surface_text: He points out that undoubtedly an industrial dispute had arisen ... resort could be taken by the State Government only to the special provisions of cl. d and not to the more general provisions of cl. b of s. 3.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rovisions and also so as to render the statute or any of its provisions companystitutional. By limiting the operation of the provisions of cl.  b  to

arguments.court_reasoning: Normal is judicial but cl. b for emergency as temporary/interim

arguments.claim: Proviso shows cl. b temporary; government has discretion to refuse reference under cl. d

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak, however, stated that under this section, the Government has a discretion whether or not to refer a dispute for conciliation or adjudication under cl. d .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ith the Constitution, they have been rendered void. In our view, therefore, the provisions of cl.  b  of s. 3 are number in any sense alternative to t

arguments.court_reasoning: After cl. b, government cannot refuse reference; mandamus possible

arguments.claim: Nothing in cl. b limits to emergency

anchor.surface_text: There is a further argument of Mr. Pathak which must be noticed and that argument is that there is nothing in cl. b which limits its operation to an emergency and that it is, therefore, not open to us to place a construction thereon of the kind we are placing.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: would still be there and companyld be exercised by them by taking appropriate steps. Upon the companystruction we place on the provisions of cl.  b  o

arguments.court_reasoning: Opening words of s.3 indicate emergency; acute emergency justifies cl. b

arguments.claim: Construe statute harmoniously to avoid conflict between provisions and ensure constitutionality

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f Art. 13, have only a limited effect as stated above and to the extent that they are inconsistent with the Constitution, they have been rendered void

arguments.court_reasoning: Court applies to limit cl. b to emergency

arguments.claim: Dispute existed in present when order made, though origin past

anchor.surface_text: It must not be forgotten that the dispute was in the present, that is, it existed when the impugned order was made, though its origin was in the past.

arguments.claim: Cl. b enacted for emergency; temporary order per words and proviso

anchor.surface_text: Clause b of s. 3 was apparently enacted for this purpose. An order made thereunder would be in the nature of a temporary or interim order as would be clear from the words for such period as may be specified appearing therein

arguments.claim: Post cl. b order, government must refer under cl. d if requested; mandamus under Art.226

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. Agarwal, who appeared for the State of Uttar Pradesh conceded, and we think rightly, that this would be so and added that in case the State Government was recalcitrant it could be forced to do its duty by the issue of a writ of mandamus by the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: S.3 opening indicates emergency; cl.b for acute emergencies

anchor.surface_text: The opening words of s. 3 themselves indicate that the provisions thereof are to be availed of in an emergency. ... Such an emergency may necessitate the exercise of powers under cl. b and a mere resort to those under cl. d may be inadequate to meet this situation.

arguments.claim: Even if broad language, Art.13 limits to constitutional extent post-Constitution

anchor.surface_text: assuming that the width of the language could not be limited by construction it can be said that after the coming into force of the Constitution the provisions can, by virtue of Art. 13, have only a limited effect

arguments.claim: No discrimination under Art.14; temporary public interest restriction under Art.19(6)

anchor.surface_text: Upon the construction we place on the provisions of cl. b of s. 3 it is clear that no question of discrimination at all arises. Similarly the fact that action was taken by the Government in an emergency in the public interest would be a complete answer to the argument that that action is violative of the provisions of Art. 19 1 g . The restriction placed upon the employer by such an order is only a temporary one and having been placed in the public interest would fall under cl. 6 of Art. 19 of, the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Bhargava J. in Ram Nath Koeri reverses earlier view; supports cl. b application

anchor.surface_text: Bhargava, J.s decision was, however, reversed in Ram Nath Koeri and Another v. Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills and Ors. 2 by a division bench of the Allahabad High Court in Letters Patent Appeal brought against Bhargava, J.s decision. We agree with the view taken by the Appellate Bench.

holdings.text: Clause b of s. 3 of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 cannot be given a retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with the learned judges of the Allahabad High Court that cl. b of s. 3 cannot be given a retrospective effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court on prospective nature of statute; no retrospective operation possible.

holdings.text: The State Government's direction to pay bonus for 1947-48 and 1948-49 did not give retrospective effect to cl. b of s. 3 but imposed a condition of employment for 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: But we are unable to agree with them that the State Government in making a direction to the employers to pay bonus for the years in question purported to give a retrospective operation to the provisions of that clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direction attaches payment as future condition to ongoing employment; payable only to past workers within six weeks.

holdings.text: Payment of bonus can be imposed as a condition of employment under cl. b of s. 3.

anchor.surface_text: We agree that normally wage is a term of contract but it would be futile to say that it cannot be made a condition of employment. The Minimum Wages Act provides for the fixation of a statutory minimum wage payable to a worker

holdings.reasoning_summary: Minimum Wages Act analogy; s.3 empowers imposing terms/conditions regardless of contractual origin.

holdings.text: There is nothing in cl. b of s. 3 prohibiting direction for payment of past bonus; upheld as per appellate bench in Ram Nath Koeri.

anchor.surface_text: Bhargava, J.s decision was, however, reversed in Ram Nath Koeri and Another v. Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills and Ors. by a division bench of the Allahabad High Court in Letters Patent Appeal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows reversal of Bhargava J.; direction determines future terms, not enforces past.

holdings.text: Cl. b of s. 3 applies in acute emergencies as temporary/interim measure supplementing cl. d.

anchor.surface_text: Clause b of s. 3 was apparently enacted for this purpose. An order made thereunder would be in the nature of a temporary or interim order as would be clear from the words for such period as may be specified

holdings.reasoning_summary: Opening words of s.3 indicate emergency; proviso limits post-adjudication; normal process is cl.d but cl.b for prompt action.

holdings.text: After order under cl. b, government cannot refuse reference under cl. d; mandamus available under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: But in our opinion where once the Government has acted under cl. b on the ground that it was in the public interest to do so, it would not be open to the Government to refuse to refer the dispute under cl. d

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ensures judicial process follows executive interim order; state concession.

holdings.text: Cl. b of s. 3 must be construed to apply only in emergencies to avoid conflict with cl. d and ensure constitutionality.

anchor.surface_text: As Mr. Pathak himself suggested in the course of his arguments, we must try and construe a statute in such a way, where it is possible to so construe it, as to obviate a conflict between its various provisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; s.3 opening words; alternatively reading down via Art.13.

holdings.text: Provisions of cl. b of s. 3 not violative of Art. 14 or Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Upon the construction we place on the provisions of cl. b of s. 3 it is clear that no question of discrimination at all arises. Similarly the fact that action was taken by the Government in an emergency

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited to emergency avoids discrimination; temporary public interest restriction under Art.19(6).

holdings.text: High Court erred in quashing the bonus payment order; appeal allowed and High Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Upon this view we hold that the High Court was in error in issuing a writ against the State Government quashing their order in so far as it related to payment of bonus. The appeal is allowed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings uphold government order under cl.b.

precedents.citation: L. D. Sugar Mills v. U. P. Government  1 [A.I.R. 1954 All. 705, 714]

anchor.surface_text: L. D. Sugar Mills v. U. P. Government  1  The expression 1 to observe for such period as may be specified, such terms and companyditions of employment as may be determined gives an indication that clause  b  of s. 3 of the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, is meant for the purpose of passing orders by which the Government gives directions about what the terms and companyditions of employment should be and number how a particular term and companydition of employment already in existence should be acted upon.

precedents.case_name: L. D. Sugar Mills v. U. P. Government
precedents.cited_proposition: clause b of s. 3 of the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, is meant for the purpose of passing orders by which the Government gives directions about what the terms and conditions of employment should be and not how a particular term and condition of employment already in existence should be acted upon

precedents.citation: Ram Nath Koeri and Another v. Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills and Ors.  2 [1956 II L. L. J. 11]

anchor.surface_text: Bhargava, J.s decision was, however, reversed in Ram Nath Koeri and Another v. Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills and Ors.  2  by a division bench of the Allahabad High Court in Letters Patent Appeal brought against Bhargava, J.s decision. We agree with the view taken by the Appellate Bench.
